abstract.p: T he meta-analysis by Mertens et al. (1) interprets nudges 1 as a generally effective technique for increasing desirable 2 decision-making, with an overall pooled effect size of d = 3 0.43. This research also reports large systematic variations 4 (meta-analytic heterogeneity) in effects, primarily attributed 5 to moderators such as the domain, as well as asymmetrically 6 distributed effects, interpreted as moderate publication bias. 7 Apart from publication bias, non-normality and high het-8 erogeneity may be problematic for the representativeness of 9 meta-analytic means (2). Here, we reanalyze the corrected 10 data made available by Mertens et al. (1), finding evidence that 11 nudges have more limited than general effectiveness. We show 12 that effects are clearly left-truncated, likely due to substantial 13 publication bias, consistent with another reanalysis (3). We 14 also find that most of the pooled effects as reported in Mertens 15 et al. (1) are overestimated and hence unrepresentative. 16 First, we visualize the distributions of effects, by domain, 17 using raincloud plots (4), see Figure 1. Four domains (Finance, 18 Food, Other, and Pro-Social) show a concerning pattern of 19 sharply left-truncated tails at or slightly below zero. div.p: Author note: This version of the letter was accepted in PNAS on May 27, 2022. The previously (accepted) version used the original data, this one uses the corrected data. Differences are minor. Also, this version has been copy-edited. A reply to this letter from the authors of the original paper (Mertens et al.) is forthcoming.

figure.figDesc: Raincloud plots of individual effects by domain and all effects. The rain is the reported effects from papers, jittered vertically, and the cloud is the smoothed distribution of effects. The short wide vertical gray lines on each cloud depict the corresponding meta-analytic mean. The single tall thin vertical gray line is an effect size of zero.
